newsitem.title: INDIA: India call ends easy, gilt prices up in light trade.
newsitem.headline: India call ends easy, gilt prices up in light trade.

text.p: Indian call money ended Wednesday at 7.5-8.5 percent against the Tuesday's close of 8.75-9.25 as the impact of central bank dollar purchases was felt by the domestic money market, dealers said.
Call money opened Wednesdayt at 8.0-9.0 percent.
Dealers said Reserve Bank of India (RBI) dollar purchases injected liquidity into the banking system and helped push call money rates down.
Dealers estimate RBI's combined dollar purchases on Monday and Tuesday at $300-400 million. The RBI bought dollars again on Wednesday, pushing the rupee down against the dollar.
"They (RBI) were buying spot dollars," said a dealer. "So rupees came in today from Monday's (dollar) purchases."

Dealers said call money could be easy next week on inflows from RBI's continuing forex market intervention and interest payments on government securities despite a 30 billion rupee bond issue on Friday.
The RBI auctions 30 billion rupees of five-year central government bonds on May 9.
Dealers said they expected a cut-off rate of around 12.60 percent at the auction despite secondary market yields of around 12.75 percent for securities of similar maturity.
Dealers said there were indications from the RBI it wanted banks to bid at lower yields at the auction than current secondary market yields.

"Current high call money rates are an aberration and have pushed yields up," said a dealer. "Rates should come down to around 6.0 percent next week. So 12.60 percent may be reasonable for five-year paper."
Interbank term money rates rose to 9.0-9.5 percent for 30 days maturity, dealers said.
Last week 90-day money had been quoted in the same range.
Prices of government securities rose in thin trade, dealers said.
The 13.05 percent 2007 government stock was in demand and buying by an insurance company moved its price up 100.55 rupees from 100.10, dealers said.
The 13.85 percent 2000 stock rose to 105.25 rupees from 104.25, 13.50 percent 1997 to 101.64 from 101.50 and 13.50 percent 1998 to 102.70 from 102.45, dealers said.
Yields on treasury bills maturing in April 1998 fell to 9.30 percent from 9.35 percent, dealers said.
The money market is largely inactive on Thursday as banks in India's commercial capital of Bombay are closed for a local holiday. They reopen on Friday.
